results.title: The Fire in the Stone
results.creator_credit: G Conway, Pamela Vanneck and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Colin Thiele, tells the story of Ernie, a teenager living in Coober Pedy with his no-hoper father. Ernie dreams of re-uniting his separated mother and father with the proceeds from the opal he is going to find one day. His dream, however, becomes a nightmare, when he stumbles across a small fortune in opals … which are then stolen. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: G Conway, Pamela Vanneck and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: The Film school generation
results.creator_credit: Steve Jenkins, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “American cinema”.
Maverick filmmakers of the 1960’s and 1970’s including Brian DePalma, Martin Scorsese and Steven Spielberg, capitalized on new technology and borrowed from the classical Hollywood and French New Wave as they as they reinvented the American film. The financial and cultural forces that contributed to their success and commercial clout are explored.

results.title: Romantic comedy
results.creator_credit: Molly Ornati, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “American cinema”.
Breezy and silly to witty and intelligent, romantic comedies have been around since the 1930’s but the surface humour barely masked issues of gender and sexuality. This program reviews screwball comedies including “It happened one night” and “His girl Friday” and analyses more recent interpretations of the genre by directors like Nora Ephron and James Brooks.

results.title: The Finished people
results.creator_credit: Khoa Do, Open Family Australia and Post 75 Productions
results.brief_description: A fine example of low budget filmmaking executed with a realistic fervour. Set in Sydney’s Cabramatta, three homeless youth struggle with the boredom, danger and many frustrations of life on the streets. Tommy (Jason McGoldrick) tries to overcome his drug addiction that started at a very young age. Van (Joe Le) sleeps in a car park but finds an unlikely camaraderie with a girl named Carla. Des (Rodney Anderson) gets involved with crims to try and etch out a living for himself and his pregnant girlfriend. Portrayed with a realism brought about by a young cast performing for film for the first time and based on a script written by those living a hard life, “The Finished People” provides a powerful insight into the world of homeless youth in suburban Australia. Although sometimes grim, moments of true human connection demonstrate that these young adults are not ‘Finished People’ at all.

results.title: The Final Academy Documents 1982
results.brief_description: The second video in the ‘Final Academy Documents’ contains William S. Burroughs reading his novel and John Giorno reading his poetry to music recorded at the “Fianl Academy” evening at the Hacienda Club in Manchester in 1982.

results.title: The Flight of the snows
results.creator_credit: Jean-Louis Frund, Donald Duprey, International Cinemedia Centre Ltd and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The snow goose is a tightly scheduled bird. It winters in the United States, flies 4,000 kilometres to breed and raise a family in the high Arctic, and returns before the frost sets in. This film documents the formation-flying, feeding habits, rearing of young and lifestyle of the great snow goose. Written by Joseph Koenig; music by James Solkin; voice and narration by Bud Knapp.

results.title: The Studio system
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “American cinema”.
This program surveys Hollywood’s industrial past during the era of contract players and directors, studio police forces and colourful movie moguls. It also overviews the modern film-making environment with studio heads Michael Eisner, Howard Koch and others. Paramount Pictures, one of the oldest and most successful of the Hollywood studios, serves as a case study.

results.title: The Final academy documents 1962/63
results.brief_description: Contains archival film footage of William S. Burroughs and Brion Gysin, filmed by the late Anthony Balch in 1962-1963. Includes “Ghosts at Number 9” and the classic film “Towers Open Fire”.

results.title: The Filth and the fury
results.creator_credit: Julien Temple, Amanda Temple, Anita Camarata, Nitrate Films and Jersey Shore
results.brief_description: This honest film is suitable for both fans of the band and social historians. The documentary traces the dramatic rise and fall of the Sex Pistols in 70s London, using a collage of interesting footage from the time of chaos and rebellion. Throughout the film Shakespeare’s “Richard III” is irreverently referred to as being emblematic of the Sex Pistols being a band created during a time ripe for rebellion and individuality. The band members are interviewed in the shadows as if to keep their current identities hidden. These members give a personal account - as a voice over - throughout the documentary, bringing to life the rare footage of the punk movement.

results.title: Film in the television age
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Foster, Alain Klarer, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “American cinema”.
Television arrived in American homes just as the Hollywood studio system was collasping. As the new medium took hold, so did a new era in motion picture entertainment. Renown directors, film scholars and actors trace the influence of each medium upon the other; from the live and fresh dramas of the Golden Age of Television and the growth of Hollywood spectacles to the modern day megalithic entertainment industry.
